results_summary: The study found that 400 IU/day of vitamin D adequately supported GMD, while 1200 IU/day modestly enhanced GMD in winter/spring-born children. No significant influence of season-at-birth was observed with the standard 400 IU/day dose.
population_specificity: Healthy infants (n=116 initially, n=70 at follow-up).
study_duration: 1 to 12 months of supplementation, with follow-up at 3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation improves gut microbiota diversity in patients with Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) and vitamin D insufficiency.
results_summary: The study found that gut microbiota alpha diversity increased significantly in the recovery state compared to the CDI state. Vitamin D supplementation was associated with changes in bacterial relative abundance, though specific beneficial bacteria were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with CDI and vitamin D insufficiency (vitamin D level < 17 ng/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation improves statin-associated muscle symptoms (SAMS) in patients with mild-moderate vitamin D insufficiency.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation was associated with improved statin tolerance in 83.9% of patients across 7 studies, though the observed association may be confounded by placebo and nocebo effects due to the lack of randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Adult patients (mean age 59.5-64.8 years, predominantly Caucasian) with SAMS and mild-moderate vitamin D insufficiency (pre-treatment levels 17.8-22.0 ng/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the current evidence regarding vitamin D's potential role in COVID-19 and its future as a preventive public health measure.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D deficiency is associated with various diseases, including COVID-19, and suggests that vitamin D may act as an immunomodulator, supporting its potential role in mitigating COVID-19 severity and prevalence. High-dose supplementation for hospitalized COVID-19 patients and targeted supplementation for high-risk populations were recommended.
population_specificity: High-risk populations and COVID-19 hospitalized patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the real-world effectiveness of vitamin D supplementation in reducing knee pain and improving physical function in patients with knee osteoarthritis by emulating a randomized controlled trial design.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation (≥1,000 IU/day for ≥4 days/week) did not significantly improve knee pain, physical function, or joint space width over 2 years compared to controls, with effect sizes consistent with previous RCTs.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥45 with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis who had not taken vitamin D supplements in the past 30 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of vitamin D supplementation on cardiovascular disease (CVD) outcomes in adults with prediabetes.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation did not significantly reduce major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) but had a small favorable effect on ASCVD risk score. No significant differences were observed in individual CVD risk factors between the vitamin D and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Adults with prediabetes and intermediate CVD risk, mean age 60 years, 45% women, 13% with history of CVD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation could serve as a beneficial treatment for hypertensive patients, particularly those with vitamin D deficiency, by analyzing RCT data.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation was ineffective in reducing blood pressure in vitamin D-sufficient normotensive subjects but may reduce hypertension risk in vitamin D-deficient individuals after five or more years. Daily or weekly supplementation showed BP reduction in vitamin D-deficient hypertensive patients, unlike large bolus dosing.
population_specificity: Participants were categorized into four groups: vitamin D-sufficient normotensive, vitamin D-deficient normotensive, vitamin D-sufficient hypertensive, and vitamin D-deficient hypertensive.
effective_dosage: Daily or weekly supplementation (specific amounts not detailed)
study_duration: Five years or more for risk reduction; duration varied across studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on platelet-mediated inflammation in vitamin-D-deficient type 2 diabetes (T2DM) patients.
results_summary: Six months of vitamin D supplementation increased serum vitamin D3 and total 25(OH)D levels and reduced oxidative stress and platelet-mediated inflammation in T2DM patients, suggesting potential benefits for reducing cardiovascular risk.
population_specificity: Vitamin-D-deficient type 2 diabetes (T2DM) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vitamin D3 supplementation could improve biomarkers of oxidative stress in children with ADHD.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly increased circulating 25(OH)D levels but did not reduce oxidative stress biomarkers (8-isoprostan, PON-1, TAC) compared to placebo. No statistically significant differences in oxidative stress markers were observed between the treatment and control groups.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-12 diagnosed with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the link between vitamin D and its receptor with eye diseases, as well as the potential role of calcitriol analogues in mitigating these disorders.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D deficiency is common in patients with ocular disorders and that vitamin D may modulate disease progression, potentially serving as a marker or therapeutic agent. However, limitations in existing studies necessitate further randomized trials for conclusive evidence.
population_specificity: Patients affected by various ocular disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vitamin D supplementation during a weight-loss program improves carotid intima-media thickness (IMT) and carotid compliance in obese adolescents.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Vitamin D's effects on carotid IMT or compliance, only stating that the study assessed these outcomes.
population_specificity: Obese adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of vitamin D supplementation in treating or preventing depressive symptoms during the perinatal period.
results_summary: The two RCTs reported improvements in depressive symptoms with vitamin D supplementation, but small sample sizes limited conclusions. Observational studies had mixed findings, and overall evidence was inconclusive due to poor study quality and heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Women in the perinatal period (antenatal and postnatal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of vitamin D supplementation on total cancer outcomes, considering dosing strategies and adiposity.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation with daily dosing reduced total cancer mortality, but infrequent large-bolus dosing did not. For cancer incidence, daily dosing benefits were limited to normal-weight individuals, while bolus dosing showed no risk reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials)
effective_dosage: Daily dosing vs. infrequent large-bolus dosing (specific amounts not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether long-term daily supplementation with marine ω-3 fatty acids (not Vitamin D) prevents the development of dry eye disease (DED).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the incidence of diagnosed DED or severe DED symptoms between participants taking marine ω-3 fatty acids and those on placebo, indicating no preventive benefit.
population_specificity: 23,523 US adults (men aged 50+ and women aged 55+) without prior DED diagnosis or severe symptoms.
effective_dosage: 1 g per day of marine ω-3 fatty acids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Vitamin D supplementation and aerobic training on inflammation and oxidative stress signaling pathways in patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found that Vitamin D supplementation, alone or combined with aerobic training, significantly improved oxidative stress biomarkers, antioxidant capacity, and inflammatory cytokine gene expression while reducing insulin resistance and inflammatory markers in T2DM patients. The combination of Vitamin D and aerobic training showed more pronounced benefits than either intervention alone.
population_specificity: 48 men with T2DM, aged 35-50 years, with a BMI of 25-30 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 50,000 IU of Vitamin D per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maternal vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy on offspring health outcomes, including mortality, growth, and vitamin D status.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy was associated with reduced risk of intrauterine/neonatal death, increased offspring length at birth, and improved neonatal vitamin D levels, but showed no significant effects on birth weight, head circumference, preterm birth, or low birth weight. Early supplementation (before 20 weeks) reduced the risk of small for gestational age.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their offspring.
effective_dosage: Not specified (compared to placebo or ≤400 IU/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of adequate vitamin D levels by day +30 post-supplementation on early outcomes after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), including aGVHD, immune recovery, infection rates, and overall survival.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in neutrophil and platelet engraftment times between patients with normal and low vitamin D levels at day +30, but slower CD4 immune recovery was observed at day +100 in the low vitamin D group.
population_specificity: Forty children aged 2 to 16 years undergoing HSCT.
study_duration: Supplementation administered until at least day +30 post-transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of high-dose cholecalciferol supplementation on serum levels of angiogenic markers in non-diabetic patients with stage 3-4 chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: Cholecalciferol supplementation significantly improved flow-mediated dilatation (FMD) and altered levels of angiogenic markers, including a decrease in angiopoietin-2 and changes in angiopoietin-1 and VEGF-R, though some changes were also observed in the placebo group. The study suggests potential effects on angiogenesis but requires further confirmation.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic patients aged 18-70 with stage 3-4 CKD and vitamin D deficiency (serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D ≤20 ng/ml).
effective_dosage: Two directly observed oral doses of 300,000 IU cholecalciferol at baseline and 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of vitamin D supplementation on COVID-19 related outcomes, including infection risk, hospitalization, ICU admission, and mortality.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation showed no significant effect on COVID-19 infection risk but was associated with reduced ICU admission and mortality in hospitalized patients. No meta-analysis was possible for hospitalization risk due to insufficient data.
population_specificity: Uninfected individuals (primary prevention), mild COVID-19 cases (secondary prevention), and hospitalized COVID-19 patients (tertiary prevention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single high dose of vitamin D3 improves 14-day survival in older adults with COVID-19 compared to a standard dose.
results_summary: High-dose vitamin D3 reduced 14-day mortality compared to standard-dose (6% vs. 11%), but this effect was not sustained at 28 days. No increased adverse effects were observed with the high dose.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥65 with COVID-19 and at least one worsening risk factor (e.g., age ≥75, low oxygen levels).
effective_dosage: Single oral dose of 400,000 IU (high-dose) vs. 50,000 IU (standard-dose).
study_duration: Single administration within 72 hours of COVID-19 diagnosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of vitamin D metabolic disorder in pancreatitis and evaluate the potential benefits of vitamin D supplementation in its management.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D deficiency is associated with pancreatitis and that vitamin D exhibits anti-inflammatory and anti-fibrotic effects via VDR signaling. However, the role of vitamin D assessment and its management in pancreatitis remains poorly understood, and further research is needed.
population_specificity: Patients with acute pancreatitis (AP) and chronic pancreatitis (CP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between vitamin D receptor (VDR) gene polymorphism and TB risk, as well as the impact of vitamin D supplementation on TB treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent evidence regarding the benefits of vitamin D supplementation for TB outcomes, but suggested further large-scale epidemiological research to explore interactions between VDR polymorphism, vitamin D status, and TB treatment results.
population_specificity: TB patients across different ethnic populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current knowledge on the relationship between vitamin D and obesity/adiposity in humans and rodents, and the impact of maternal vitamin D deficiency on offspring metabolism.
results_summary: Observational studies show an inverse relationship between vitamin D levels and obesity, but interventional and genetic studies provide unclear conclusions. Vitamin D supplementation in obese rodents mostly failed to improve obesity, but some evidence suggests a preventive effect on obesity onset. Maternal vitamin D deficiency may program adipose tissue biology in offspring.
population_specificity: Humans and rodents, with a focus on maternal vitamin D deficiency and offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single high oral dose of vitamin D3 could prevent respiratory worsening in hospitalized patients with mild-to-moderate COVID-19 and risk factors for disease progression.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between vitamin D3 and placebo groups in respiratory worsening, length of hospital stay, ICU admissions, or in-hospital mortality. Serious adverse events were also similar between groups.
population_specificity: Hospitalized adult patients with confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection, mild-to-moderate COVID-19, and risk factors for disease progression.
effective_dosage: Single oral dose of 500,000 IU of vitamin D3.
study_duration: Single dose, with outcomes assessed up to day 7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of vitamin D supplementation for treating fibromyalgia through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D significantly reduced Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire scores compared to placebo but showed no statistical difference in Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) pain scores.
population_specificity: 315 participants with fibromyalgia across five studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if modest Vitamin D supplementation enhances body composition changes (increased bone and lean mass, decreased fat mass) and performance in collegiate basketball players after 12 weeks of standardized training.
results_summary: The study involved 18 collegiate basketball players, with 10 receiving Vitamin D supplementation (~517 IU/day) and 8 receiving a placebo. The abstract does not provide specific results on body composition or performance changes, but implies conclusions were drawn about Vitamin D's effects.
population_specificity: NCAA Division 1 collegiate basketball players (8 females, 10 males).

study_goal: The researchers sought to evaluate the effectiveness of Vitamin D supplementation in reducing the risk of preterm birth, particularly in low/middle-income countries.
results_summary: The study found that Vitamin D supplementation showed a greater effect size and consistency in reducing preterm birth risk among the interventions reviewed. However, the abstract does not provide detailed statistical outcomes or clinical relevance specific to Vitamin D.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, particularly in low/middle-income countries where preterm birth burden is highest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of calcifediol (a form of Vitamin D) on physical performance and muscle strength, particularly in older adults at risk of sarcopenia.
results_summary: Calcifediol significantly improved gait speed, handgrip strength, and leg extension compared to baseline values, suggesting positive effects on muscle strength parameters, though evidence for physical performance was less conclusive.
population_specificity: Older adults at higher risk of vitamin D deficiency and sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of vitamin D in the pathogenesis and treatment of osteosarcopenic obesity.
results_summary: The study found that while vitamin D deficiency is linked to osteosarcopenic obesity, clinical evidence supporting its efficacy in improving musculoskeletal health is lacking or even shows detrimental effects in some trials. Large interventional studies are needed to clarify its role.
population_specificity: Individuals with osteosarcopenic obesity, with a focus on different sex, age, and race groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the associations between maternal vitamin D status and intake during pregnancy and the development of atopic diseases (asthma, eczema, food allergies) in children up to 5 years, including potential effect modification by atopic heredity.
results_summary: Higher maternal vitamin D status and intake during pregnancy were associated with an increased risk of atopic diseases in children without reported atopic heredity, while lower maternal vitamin D levels (50-75 nmol/L) in early pregnancy were linked to reduced asthma risk in this group. No significant associations were found for children with atopic heredity.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their offspring up to 5 years of age.
effective_dosage: Not specified (measured via serum 25OHD levels and dietary intake estimates).
study_duration: Pregnancy (early and late stages) and follow-up until child age 5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of the vitamin D endocrine system (VDES) in human fertility, pregnancy outcomes, and related endocrinopathies, as well as assess the safety and efficacy of calcifediol treatment.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D deficiency is linked to fertility issues, pregnancy complications, and endocrinopathies, but there is no consensus on optimal treatment dosage. Calcifediol appears safe, even during pregnancy, but large clinical studies are needed to confirm benefits and establish dosing guidelines.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age, pregnant women, and individuals with fertility-related conditions (e.g., polycystic ovary disease, uterine fibroids).

study_goal: To assess the effect of oral vitamin D3 supplementation on dry eye symptoms in patients who underwent FS-LASIK surgery.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D3 supplementation significantly improved dry eye symptoms (lower OSDI scores) and tear film stability (higher TBUT and Schirmer I test values) compared to the control group, with effects sustained at 1, 3, and 6 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: 90 patients who underwent FS-LASIK surgery and exhibited dry eye symptoms one month post-operation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the associations between vitamin D and irritable bowel disease (IBS) through a meta-analysis of clinical trials.
results_summary: The study found that IBS patients had low serum vitamin D levels, and supplementation improved quality of life (QoL) scores but did not significantly affect symptom severity (SSS). Vitamin D deficiency was associated with IBS pathogenesis.
population_specificity: 1,331 patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the association between vitamin D and coronary artery disease (CAD), its therapeutic applications, and its role in cardiovascular health.
results_summary: Observational studies and meta-analyses consistently show an association between vitamin D and CAD prevalence, severity, and cardiovascular risk factors, but supplementation results in primary prevention are inconsistent, with limited data for patients with established CAD.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) and general populations in observational studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on improving insulin resistance in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation improved insulin resistance (reduced HOMA-IR), increased serum vitamin D levels, and decreased ALT levels, but had no effect on AST levels. The study concluded that vitamin D may serve as a potential adjunctive treatment for NAFLD.
population_specificity: NAFLD patients (735 participants across 7 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether correcting vitamin D deficiency in diabetic macular edema (DME) patients improves treatment outcomes when combined with intravitreal bevacizumab (IVB).
results_summary: The study found that correcting vitamin D deficiency alongside IVB treatment led to more significant improvements in visual acuity and central macular thickness compared to IVB alone in vitamin D-deficient patients, though the benefits appeared delayed by several months.
population_specificity: 83 patients with diabetic macular edema (DME) and varying vitamin D levels (normal, insufficient, or deficient).
effective_dosage: Not specified (oral vitamin D supplementation dosage not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: 6 months (follow-up after three monthly IVB loading doses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Stimunex (a food supplement) could prevent recurrent respiratory infections (RRI) in children by modulating the immune system and resolving inflammation.
results_summary: Children treated with Stimunex showed reduced frequency and duration of respiratory infections, improved parental perception of symptom severity and treatment efficacy, and decreased medication use and school/work absences compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 298 children with recurrent respiratory infections (RRI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the reduction in cancer mortality achieved by current vitamin D fortification policies in Europe and the potential for further reductions if all countries implemented effective fortification.
results_summary: Current vitamin D fortification is estimated to prevent approximately 11,000 cancer deaths annually in the EU and 27,000 in all considered European countries. If all countries implemented adequate fortification, an additional 129,000 cancer deaths could be prevented, corresponding to nearly 1.2 million prevented years of life lost.
population_specificity: European countries (34 countries analyzed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate adherence to standard guidelines for adjunctive vitamin D therapy in pediatric diseases and assess the impact of socioeconomic status on vitamin D consumption.
results_summary: The study found poor adherence to standard guidelines for vitamin D testing and dosing in pediatric diseases, with significant associations between socioeconomic status and vitamin D consumption. Adjunctive vitamin D was prescribed across multiple diseases, but adherence to recommended practices was low.
population_specificity: 400 ambulatory pediatric patients at Children's Hospital, Pakistan Institute of Medical Sciences Islamabad.
study_duration: Data collected from November 2017 to June 2018 (study duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether calcitriol supplementation enhances CD4 levels in treatment-naïve tuberculosis patients with low Vitamin D levels.
results_summary: The study found that calcitriol supplementation elevated CD4 levels in the Low-25(OH)D-Calcitriol group compared to the Low-25(OH)D group, suggesting a beneficial effect on immune function in tuberculosis patients.
population_specificity: Treatment-naïve tuberculosis patients with low Vitamin D levels (25(OH)D < 75 nmol/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation improves symptoms in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that vitamin D supplementation significantly reduced IBS severity scores compared to placebo, suggesting it may be an effective treatment for IBS. The results were statistically significant with a notable effect size.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) (335 participants across four trials).

study_goal: To review the mechanisms by which vitamin D regulates the immune system and its role in preventing/treating SARS-CoV2 and other respiratory infections.
results_summary: Vitamin D deficiency is associated with increased risk of SARS-CoV2 and respiratory infections. Clinical trials show that correcting deficiency reduces hospitalization, ICU admission, and death from SARS-CoV2.
population_specificity: General population with focus on respiratory infections and SARS-CoV2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of vitamin D in liver cancer development and its potential antineoplastic effects through basic and clinical studies.
results_summary: Basic studies showed vitamin D suppresses hepatic stellate and Kupffer cell activity, with anti-proliferative, anti-angiogenic, proapoptotic, and prodifferentiative effects on liver cancer cells. Clinical observational studies were promising but inconclusive, and no reliable data exists on vitamin D supplementation's effect on liver cancer occurrence or survival.
population_specificity: Liver cancer patients and chronic liver disease patients (indirectly referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of different dosages and intervals of vitamin D supplementation on fracture and fall risks.
results_summary: Daily vitamin D doses of 800 to 1,000 IU were associated with reduced risks of osteoporotic fractures and falls, while doses outside this range or intermittent administration showed no significant benefit. Patients with vitamin D deficiency experienced significant risk reduction in falls after supplementation.
population_specificity: Patients at risk of fractures and falls, particularly those with vitamin D deficiency.
study_duration: Follow-up duration of at least 6 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the molecular effects of vitamin D on inflammation and glucose regulation in diabetes-associated periodontitis.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation reduced inflammatory cytokines and immune cell counts, mediated through specific molecular pathways, and showed antibacterial effects. It also influenced glucose homeostasis, though hyperglycemia may alter glucoregulatory factors.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes-associated periodontitis.

study_goal: To determine the efficacy and safety of Vitamin D supplementation in preventing SARS-CoV-2 infection in highly exposed individuals.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation (4,000 IU daily) significantly reduced SARS-CoV-2 infection rates compared to placebo (6.4% vs. 24.5%) and was associated with increased serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 levels. No significant adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Frontline healthcare workers in Mexico City who tested negative for SARS-CoV-2 at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation reduces the incidence of postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF) and improves recovery outcomes in patients undergoing CABG surgery.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly reduced the incidence of POAF (9.68% vs. 20.39%) and shortened ICU and hospital stays compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing CABG surgery with vitamin D insufficiency (25(OH)D < 30 ng/ml).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess adherence to vitamin D supplementation recommendations in children aged 0-4 years, compare serum vitamin D levels across global regions and genders, and evaluate seasonal variation.
results_summary: Adherence to vitamin D supplementation was very low (59/363 children). Vitamin D deficiency was common (42%) in unsupplemented children, with girls from the Indian subcontinent, Middle East, and Africa having the lowest levels. Seasonal variation was observed in certain regions.
population_specificity: 2502 children aged 0-17 years, including immigrant populations in Sweden.
study_duration: Data collected between 22 January 2004 and 17 May 2021 (observational, not intervention duration)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the associations between maternal and offspring genetic variations in the vitamin D metabolism pathway and umbilical cord blood 25(OH)D levels, including in women who received antenatal cholecalciferol supplementation.
results_summary: The study found associations between maternal and offspring SNPs (rs2282679 and rs12785878) and cord blood 25(OH)D levels, with persisting evidence after adjustments. No associations were found for SNPs rs1074657 and rs613897.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their offspring, including participants from an observational cohort and a clinical trial.
effective_dosage: 1000 IU/day cholecalciferol (in the clinical trial arm).
study_duration: Duration of pregnancy (specific length not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D3 supplementation could correct vitamin D deficiency in patients with type 2 diabetes without causing hypervitaminosis.
results_summary: The study found that weekly vitamin D3 supplementation significantly increased serum vitamin D levels in patients with type 2 diabetes, achieving levels above 30 ng/ml without reaching hypervitaminosis thresholds. No significant changes were observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 62 patients with type 2 diabetes and hypovitaminosis D3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the antiviral efficacy, tolerance, and safety of high-dose cholecalciferol (10,000 IU/day) in COVID-19 pneumonia patients with low vitamin D levels.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study was designed to evaluate whether vitamin D could reduce excessive inflammatory immune responses and improve outcomes in COVID-19 patients.
population_specificity: Patients with COVID-19 pneumonia and low 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels (mean 14.8 ng/ml, SD: 6.18).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the correlation between vitamin D deficiency and PCOS, and the potential benefits of vitamin D supplementation on reproductive health and IVF outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D deficiency correlates with PCOS severity and that supplementation improves fertility and IVF outcomes, reduces pregnancy-related complications, and may prevent reversible bone loss in mothers.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and those undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether MK-7 (vitamin K2) plus vitamin D supplementation could reduce the progression of aortic valve calcification (AVC) in elderly men with aortic stenosis.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in AVC progression between the intervention group (MK-7 plus vitamin D) and the placebo group after 24 months. Secondary outcomes, including changes in aortic valve area and peak aortic jet velocity, also showed no meaningful differences.
population_specificity: Elderly men (mean age 71.0 years) with an AVC score >300 arbitrary units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D3 supplementation affects HIV disease progression, viral suppression, comorbidities, weight change, and depression in HIV-infected adults initiating antiretroviral therapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of vitamin D3 supplementation on HIV progression, viral suppression, comorbidities, weight-related indicators, or depression compared to placebo.
population_specificity: HIV-infected adult men and nonpregnant women with insufficient serum 25(OH)D concentrations (<30 ng/mL) initiating ART in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.
effective_dosage: Weekly 50,000 IU for 4 weeks followed by daily 2000 IU.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential role of vitamin D in long COVID-19 and summarize current literature on this topic.
results_summary: The abstract suggests vitamin D has immunomodulatory effects and may help with hyperinflammatory reactions and lung healing in COVID-19, but no studies have found it affects post-COVID-19 symptoms or biomarkers.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients, particularly those with acute respiratory failure or vitamin D deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential effect of vitamin D on juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) disease manifestations and outcomes, including its role in bone metabolism and immune modulation.
results_summary: The study reviewed vitamin D's immunomodulatory effects and its importance for bone health, suggesting potential benefits for JIA patients, but did not provide conclusive clinical outcomes from supplementation studies.
population_specificity: Children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between vitamin D status/supplementation and COVID-19 severity in older adults hospitalized for COVID-19.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation was associated with fewer severe COVID-19 forms and ICU admissions, but no relationship was found between serum 25(OH)D levels and severity. The study suggests a potential protective effect of pre-infection supplementation.
population_specificity: Older adults (average age 78 years) hospitalized for COVID-19 during the first wave of the pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current technological status, clinical validation methodologies, and clinical efficacy of wearable lower-limb exoskeletons for gait rehabilitation in people with neuromuscular impairments.
results_summary: Wearable exoskeletons show potential for early rehabilitation, physical exercise promotion, and daily living activities, improving mobility and independence in non-ambulatory individuals. However, limitations include bulky devices requiring supervision and limited evidence from short-intervention trials with few participants.
population_specificity: People with neuromuscular impairments

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and feasibility of telerehabilitation, including walking, for patients with respiratory tract diseases, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: Most telerehabilitation programs included walking as part of aerobic exercises, with low reported adverse events and high adherence rates (>70%). The findings suggest telerehabilitation, including walking, is safe and feasible for respiratory patients.
population_specificity: Patients with stable COPD and hospitalized patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of inertial sensors for monitoring gait impairments and symptoms in Parkinson's disease patients during free-living conditions.
results_summary: Inertial sensors effectively captured gait impairments (e.g., gait cycle duration, step length, velocity) and achieved over 90% accuracy in symptom assessment (e.g., bradykinesia, tremor) in free-living environments. The technology shows potential for long-term monitoring of motor status in PD patients.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine if the T4H program, involving home helpers as exercise coaches using IT devices, could reduce falls and maintain exercise capacity in older adults.
results_summary: The T4H program showed higher satisfaction rates among participants and a trend toward fewer falls and hospitalizations, though differences were not statistically significant. No significant improvements were observed in walking ability (TUG test) or self-care ability (Barthel Index).
population_specificity: Older adults aged 75 years and over, living independently at home, with a majority being women (68.6%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare oxygen consumption and energy expenditure during activities of daily living, particularly walking, between people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and healthy controls.
results_summary: PwMS exhibited significantly higher oxygen consumption and energy expenditure rates during walking tasks compared to healthy controls, with the largest differences observed in stair climbing and walking activities. Total energy expenditure to complete these activities was also significantly higher in PwMS, contributing to their reported fatigue.
population_specificity: 24 moderately impaired people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and 21 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tDCS applied during walking reduces dual-task costs in older adults and compared its effects when applied during seated rest or sham stimulation.
results_summary: tDCS delivered during challenging walking reduced dual-task costs to gait speed and improved other gait measures and cognitive performance, while tDCS during seated rest or sham stimulation showed no significant effects. Postural sway was unaffected by tDCS.
population_specificity: 25 healthy older adults (mean age 73.9 ± 5.2 years)
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of anodal tDCS targeting M1 and lDLPFC

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate patient-reported outcomes (symptoms, activities, and quality of life) in pulmonary hypertension (PH) patients using the CAMPHOR questionnaire during pharmacy consultations.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant differences in symptom, activity, and quality-of-life domains when comparing WHO Functional Class, with the activities domain also showing differences based on the 6-minute walking test. Quality-of-life scores were worse for patients with recent emergency visits or hospitalizations.
population_specificity: Patients receiving specific treatment for pulmonary hypertension at a tertiary hospital in Madrid, Spain.
study_duration: Cross-sectional study (data collected between August and December 2019)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of prolonged-release fampridine (PR-FAM) on cognition, fatigue, depression, and quality of life in adult patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) in a real-world setting.
results_summary: PR-FAM treatment resulted in significant improvements in cognition (PASAT-3''), fatigue (MFIS), depression (BDI-II), and quality of life (MusiQoL, MSIS-29-PHYS, MSIS-29-PSYCH) at 6 months, with some positive effects evident as early as 3 months.
population_specificity: Adult patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) in Greece.
effective_dosage: As per PR-FAM's local prescribing information (specific dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of music-based movement therapy on motor function, balance, gait, mental health, and quality of life in individuals with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found that music-based movement therapy significantly improved motor function, balance, freezing of gait, walking velocity, and mental health in Parkinson's disease patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (598 participants across 17 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) on gait motion parameters and walking performance in children.
results_summary: The study found that children with JIA exhibit slower gait velocity, shortened step length, decreased range of motion at the hip, knee, and ankle, decreased joint power, and altered pelvic and trunk positioning. There is potential for exercise and pharmaceutical interventions to improve these gait changes.
population_specificity: Children with any subtype of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA).
